title: 106_s2310
content: The "Firearms Dealer Penalty Flexibility Act of 2000" allows for the suspension of a firearms dealer's license and imposes civil penalties. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, allows the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations related to armor-piercing ammunition transfers. The Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke a dealer's license or impose a civil penalty of up to $10,000 for willfully transferring armor-piercing ammunition. The Secretary also has the power to compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for any violations under this chapter. Any actions taken by the Secretary can only be reviewed as provided in subsection (f) regarding the rights of applicants and licensees. The Secretary can deny a license, revoke or suspend it, or impose a civil penalty under this chapter. The affected party must be provided with written notice stating the specific grounds for the denial, revocation, suspension, or penalty assessment. Review of the Secretary's actions can only be done as outlined in subsection (f) regarding the rights of applicants and licensees. The Secretary must provide written notice stating the specific grounds for denial, revocation, suspension, or penalty assessment. An aggrieved party can request a hearing to review the Secretary's actions. Upon request, the Secretary must promptly hold a hearing to review denial, revocation, suspension, or penalty assessment. If the decision is not reversed after the hearing, the aggrieved party will be notified. The Secretary shall provide notice of the decision to the aggrieved party. Within 60 days of receiving the notice, the aggrieved party may file a petition for judicial review in the district court for a de novo review of the denial. The aggrieved party can file a petition with the district court for a de novo judicial review of the denial, where the court can consider any evidence submitted by the parties. The district court can consider any evidence submitted by the parties, regardless of whether it was presented at the initial hearing. If the court finds that the Secretary's denial was unauthorized, they will order necessary actions to comply with the court's judgment. The court will order the Secretary to comply with its judgment by taking necessary actions if a license is suspended, revoked, or a civil penalty is assessed. Upon request, the effective date of the suspension, revocation, or assessment can be stayed pending an appeal. SEC. 3. TERMINATION OF FIREARMS DEALER'S LICENSE UPON FELONY CONVICTION. Amends Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, to change the wording regarding the termination of a firearms dealer's license upon a felony conviction.
